title: Unsupervised Discovery Of Morphemes
descriptions: This paper explores the unsupervised discovery of morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements of language, which could aid in formulating a linguistic theory of morphology for new languages. The authors propose two methods for unsupervised learning of a model, the first derived from the Minimum Description Length principle and the second using maximum likelihood of the data given the model. Both methods are applied to segmentation of Finnish and English words, with results compared to those produced by Goldsmith's Linguistica. The paper also develops a method for evaluating the quality of the morph segmentations produced by the unsupervised segmentation methods.

This paper discusses the unsupervised discovery of morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements of language. It emphasizes the importance of such methods for the formulation of a linguistic theory of morphology for new languages and their potential benefits for natural language applications dealing with large vocabularies. The paper also explores the challenges posed by languages with rich morphology, such as Finnish and Turkish, and presents two methods for unsupervised learning of a model for morph segmentation. The first method uses a Minimum Description Length (MDL) cost function and an online search algorithm, while the second method uses a maximum likelihood cost function and a batch learning algorithm. The paper concludes by comparing the results obtained from these methods to those produced by Goldsmith's Linguistica on the same data.

This paper explores the potential of unsupervised methods for discovering morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements of language. Such methods could aid in formulating a linguistic theory of morphology for new languages and improve natural language applications that deal with large vocabularies. Two methods for unsupervised learning of a model are presented: one based on the Minimum Description Length principle and an online search algorithm, and another using maximum likelihood for model optimization. The methods are evaluated for their ability to segment words into morphs and their efficiency in compressing data. The paper concludes that unsupervised methods are a promising course for future research in morphology discovery.

This paper discusses unsupervised methods for discovering morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements in language. These methods could aid linguistic theory and improve natural language applications. Two methods are proposed: the first uses a Minimum Description Length (MDL) cost function and recursive segmentation, while the second employs Maximum Likelihood (ML) learning and sequential segmentation. Both methods are evaluated for their compression efficiency and linguistic accuracy, with the MDL method showing superior performance in compressing the corpus and generalizing to new word forms. However, the paper acknowledges that the current model does not represent contextual dependencies and suggests further improvements.

The paper explores the unsupervised discovery of morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements of language, as a means to aid linguistic theory and benefit natural language applications dealing with large vocabularies. The authors propose two methods for unsupervised learning, one based on a Minimum Description Length (MDL) principle and the other on Maximum Likelihood (ML) learning. The MDL-based method utilizes an online search algorithm with a hierarchical splitting strategy for words, while the ML-based method uses a batch learning algorithm with sequential splitting. Both methods are applied to the segmentation of Finnish and English words and evaluated for their performance.

The paper explores the concept of unsupervised discovery of morphemes, the smallest meaning-bearing elements of language, which can aid in formulating a linguistic theory of morphology for new languages. The authors emphasize the benefits of automated morphological analysis for natural language applications dealing with large vocabularies, such as text retrieval and large vocabulary speech recognition. Two methods for unsupervised learning of a model are examined: one based on the Minimum Description Length principle and the other using maximum likelihood estimation. The paper also develops a method for evaluating the quality of morph segmentations produced by these methods.
